abstract.text: Implement this protocol to describe your gameplay model so that a strategist object can plan game moves.

inlineContent.text: You adopt this protocol to describe the gameplay of your turn-based game for use by a
object. The strategist uses your game model class (that is, the class you create to adopt this protocol), along with other custom classes you create (adopting the
and
protocols), to find optimal moves.
GameplayKit relies on your game model class for several parts of its strategy algorithm.
Identifying possible changes to the game state. Your
method and your move class (a custom class implementing the
protocol) describe the set of moves available during a given player’s turn.
Simulating future moves on a copy of the game. Your
method allows GameplayKit to work with a separate instance of the game model—that is, not the one representing the actual game in play—and your
uses the information in your move class to perform hypothetical moves on that separate copy of the game.
Rating the desirability of possible future states of the game. Each time GameplayKit performs a hypothetical move in its copy of the game model, it calls your
, or
method to evaluate that state of the game from the perspective of a particular player.

When you use a strategist to plan moves in your game, it uses your game model to combine these parts into a strategy: By identifying, performing, and rating the success of possible future moves, the strategist can choose a move most likely to result in a future win. This process involves using the
and

methods to evaluate many possible states of a game model—for best results, ensure that your game model class contains only the information critical to describing your game and that it can copy that state quickly.
For more information about describing your gameplay model and using a strategist, see
in

abstract.text: Returns a new instance that’s a copy of the receiver.
Architect and organize your game logic. Incorporate common gameplay behaviors such as random number generation, artificial intelligence, pathfinding, and agent behavior.
Implement this protocol to describe your gameplay model so that a strategist object can plan game moves.
The player whose turn it currently is in the game.
Updates the internal state of the game model to reflect the specified changes.
Returns the set of moves available to the specified player.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the specified player has lost the game.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the current state of the game model reflects a win for the specified player.
The players currently in the game.
Returns a number rating the desirability of the game model’s current state from the perspective of the specified player.
Sets the game model’s internal state to that of the specified game model.
Updates the internal state of the game model to remove the effect of the specified changes.
Implement this protocol to describe a player in your turn-based game so that a strategist object can plan game moves.
Implement this protocol to describe a move in your turn-based game so that a strategist object can plan game moves.

abstract.text: strategy.
A general interface for objects that provide artificial intelligence for use in turn-based (and similar) games.
Limits to values returned by the
method.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
